awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Antarctic Airborne ElectroMagnetics (ANTAEM) - Revealing Subsurface Water in Coastal Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
In Antarctica, millions of years of freezing have led to the development of hundreds of meters of thick permafrost (i.e., frozen ground). Recent research demonstrated that this slow freezing has trapped and concentrated water into local and regional briny aquifers, many times more salty than seawater. Because salt depresses the freezing point of water, these saline brines are able to persist as liquid water at temperatures well below the normal freezing point of freshwater. Such unusual groundwater systems may support microbial life, supply nutrients to coastal ocean and ice-covered lakes, and influence motion of glaciers. These briny aquifers also represent potential terrestrial analogs for deep life habitats on other planets, such as Mars, and provide a testing ground for the search for extraterrestrial water. Whereas much effort has been invested in understanding the physics, chemistry, and biology of surface and near-surface waters in cold polar regions, it has been comparably difficult to investigate deep subsurface aquifers in such settings. Airborne ElectroMagnetics (AEM) subsurface imaging provides an efficient way for mapping salty groundwater. An international collaboration with the University of Aarhus in Denmark will enable knowledge and skill transfer in AEM techniques that will enhance US polar research capabilities and provide US undergraduates and graduate students with unique training experiences. This project will survey over 1000 km2 of ocean and land near McMurdo Station in Antarctica, and will reveal if cold polar deserts hide a subsurface pool of liquid water. This will have significant implications for understanding cold polar glaciers, ice-covered lakes, frozen ground, and polar microbiology as well as for predictions of their response to future change. Improvements in permafrost mapping techniques and understanding of permafrost and of underlying groundwaters will benefit human use of high polar regions in the Antarctic and the Arctic.

The project will provide the first integrative system-scale overview of subsurface water distribution and hydrological connectivity in a partly ice-free coastal region of Antarctica, the McMurdo Dry Valleys. Liquid water is relatively scarce in this environment but plays an outsized role by influencing, and integrating, biological, biogeochemical, glaciological, and geological processes. Whereas surface hydrology and its role in ecosystem processes has been thoroughly studied over the last several decades, it has been difficult to map out and characterize subsurface water reservoirs and to understand their interactions with regional lakes, glaciers, and coastal waters. The proposed project builds on the "proof-of-concept" use of AEM technology in 2011. Improvements in sensor and data processing capabilities will result in about double the depth of penetration of the subsurface during the new data collection when compared to the 2011 proof-of-concept survey, which reached depths of 300-400m. The first field season will focus on collecting deep soundings with a ground-based system in key locations where: (i) independent constraints on subsurface structure exist from past drilling projects, and (ii) the 2011 resistivity dataset indicates the need for deeper penetration and high signal-to-noise ratios achievable only with a ground-based system. The regional airborne survey will take place during the second field season and will yield subsurface electrical resistivity data from across several valleys of different sizes and different ice cover fractions.

por.por_cntn:
Permafrost is continuously frozen ground found in the Earth's polar regions. Globally, it covers an area roughly twice the size of the United States. In Antarctica, permafrost occurs in peripheral areas of the continent that are subject to particularly cold and dry surface conditions, which in places approximate climatic conditions on Mars. There is ongoing scientific interest in using Antarctic permafrost to understand whether microbial life can persist in extreme cold conditions on Earth and other planets. Life requires liquid water, and in cold permafrost regions, water may be present below the surface where it is difficult to detect and map. Groundwater in Antarctica may provide a continental-scale habitat for microbial life. Antarctic groundwater that percolates into the coastal ocean may also fertilize marine biological productivity with nutrients such as iron, which are in short supply in the Southern Ocean. 

This project was a collaboration with scientists from the University of Aarhus, Denmark, and used their state-of-the-art helicopter-based electromagnetic sensor to map groundwater to depths of about 500 yards (about 450 meters) in the McMurdo Dry Valleys region near the main U.S. research station in Antarctica. The data showed that this groundwater is regionally extensive and connected to the coastal ocean, where it is likely to release important nutrients that support marine biological productivity. Extrapolation of these results to the entire Antarctic coast suggests that nutrients transported by groundwater may be a very important way in which water runoff from this continent stimulates biomass production in the surrounding ocean. The electrical conductivity of the detected groundwaters is low, indicating that these waters are very saline, probably many times saltier than seawater. This salinity allows the groundwater to remain liquid in the shallow subsurface where freshwater would be frozen solid. But it also means that microbial life can only use such salty groundwater as a habitat in Antarctica and on cold planets like Mars if it can cope with high salinity as well as cold temperatures and isolation in the subsurface. 

Based on the data from this Antarctic project, a theoretical paper was published on how electromagnetic waves penetrating through ice interact with the underlying conductive geological materials, and another paper on the difficulty of using radar to detect liquid water beneath the ice caps on Mars. Both papers have since been widely cited in the earth and planetary science literature, but the first also in the materials science and mining engineering literature. Collaboration with Danish specialists led to the publication of several papers focusing on improving the processing and interpretation of electromagnetic data used to detect subsurface water. These methodological developments have implications for the general improvement of the ability of electromagnetic sensors to detect subsurface water in polar regions as well as in more populated parts of our planet where groundwater is an important resource for agriculture and municipal water supply. 

An important aspect of this project was the training of undergraduate and graduate students in the use of data from the Danish electromagnetic sensor to understand the extent of groundwater and its salinity. This was particularly useful given that the development and use of helicopter-borne electromagnetic sensors for groundwater mapping is much more advanced in Denmark than in the United States. During this project, three graduate students were involved in the project at UCSC. One of them wrote his entire dissertation based on the project data. Upon graduation, this student was hired to teach geophysical methods at the University of Montana-Western. Using a subaward from this grant, he also trained four undergraduate students there in the use of the project data.  In addition, one UCSC undergraduate student completed her senior thesis based on the project data and is currently working for a private geophysical consulting firm.
